messageBody:
Dear Joe,

I don't think so. Mike Clark did a great job for many years. If you are
interested in taking over, you should negotiate with him.

Cheers,

Kent

_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Joe
Schmetzer
Sent: Monday, January 19, 2009 1:44 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Use of @Before?



Perhaps this question and answer is a good candidate for the FAQ. It
doesn't appear to have been updated in nearly three years. Is anyone still
maintaining it?

Cheers,
Joe

On Thu, January 15, 2009 2:51 pm, Piers Powlesland wrote:
> Cheers David
>
> That cleared it up for me.
>
> Ride
>
> David Saff wrote:
>>
>>
>> Ride,
>>
>> You're mostly right. A majority of what could be done in @Before methods
>> can just as well be done in field initializers or constructors. The
>> caveat
>> is if your @Before method could throw an exception: JUnit will run all
>> the
>> @Afters after a failing @Before, but it can't do that if the object
>> fails to
>> construct. So if your @Afters are globally important (releasing system
>> resources), do all risky things in @Befores. I usually generalize this
>> to
>> having one @Before for each @After, although that's not strictly
>> necessary.
>>
>> David Saff
>>
>> On Thu, Jan 15, 2009 at 6:36 AM, piersyp
>> <piers@historicaleng <mailto:piers%40historicalengineering.com>
ineering.com
>> <mailto:piers%40historicalengineering.com>>wrote:
>>
>> > Hi
>> >
>> > I am hoping someone can help me understand the use of @Before. As far
>> > as I know when JUnit runs tests a new instance is created for each
>> > testcase.
>> >
>> > So why not initialise your test variables where you define them in
>> the
>> > class or in the constructor. I can see no need for @Before.
>> >
>> > Thanks
>> >
>> > Ride
